newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Jelly roll in Computervision.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Jelly roll in Computervision.

text.p: Salomon Brothers took a bet on shares of Computervision Corp Tuesday with an esoteric transaction called a jelly roll in some long-dated options, traders said.
The Computervision January 7-1/2 call traded 3,600 contracts by late trading and the corresponding put traded 2,975. The April 7-1/2 call traded 2,775 contracts and the April 7-1/2 put traded 2,750.
Computervision shares were unchanged at 8-3/4.
"Salomon Brothers was getting long the jelly roll," said a trader on the Chicago Board Options Exchange.
A "jelly roll" is a box-type strategy for rolling parts of a conversion or a synthetic stock position.
For example, an investor long stock, long puts and short calls who rolls out a short put and long call position would have done a jelly roll.

The recently published "Dictionary of Financial Risk Management" by Gary Castineau and Mark Kritzman defines jelly roll as a transaction that offsets long and short synthetic stock or stock index positions created from options with identical strikes but different expirations.
The strategy is used to roll a synthetic stock position to a longer-dated expiration, it says.
In other trading, an investor did a buy-write in HBO & Co, traders said.

The stock fell 4-1/8 to 54-1/2 on heavy volume. The February 60 call traded 3,260 contracts, most of it in a block that crossed at 4-1/2. The option, which had open interest of 235, closed at seven on Monday.
Also, options on several technology stocks were busy as investors reacted to a sharp selloff in the sector.
The Nasdaq composite index, which is loaded with tech stocks, was down about 13 points, or one percent, at 1,203 in afternoon trade.
Technology stocks peppered the list of top net and percentage decliners.
In the group, Intel Corp fell 1-5/8 to 104-3/8, Microsoft Corp lost 1-1/4 to 135-3/8, Compaq Computer Corp was down 3-1/8 at 67-1/2 and International Business Machines Corp fell 1-3/4 to 125-5/8.
Options on Intel, Compaq and IBM were among the most active in the group.
The IBM November 130 call, with open interest of 18,400, traded more than 4,400 contracts, making it among the most active around.
The IBM November 125 put, which had open interest of about 10,850, traded 3,350.
For Compaq, the most active option was the January 70 call, which traded roughly 4,000 contracts. The option, which had open interest of about 6,930, fell two to four.
